conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for the thoughtful question.

At this stage, we cannot reliably confirm to you which specific higher-priority students are unmatched or whether they will apply in a given round. What we can clarify is our admissions policy with one remaining seat: we will continue to hold the seat for candidates higher on our priority list (Student_D, Student_A, Student_C, Student_E) while there is still meaningful time left in the process for them to approach us.

To be transparent about the condition for reconsideration: if we reach the late rounds and it appears no higher-priority candidate is coming forward to apply to School_D, we will then consider filling the seat rather than leaving it empty. If you would like a concrete checkpoint, please check back with us around rounds 20–25; at that point, if we still have the seat open and have not received applications from higher-priority candidates, we can revisit your candidacy.

If you choose to submit another formal application before then, we will acknowledge it, but our decision is unlikely to change unless the higher-priority pool clearly does not materialize.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_B is last on School_D’s true priority list, so accepting them now risks losing the chance to match with any higher-priority student (Student_D, Student_A, Student_C, Student_E) if they become available later. Student_B is only [TALK] this round, so respond with [TALK] and set a clear condition/threshold for reconsideration without committing prematurely. We cannot truly know others’ unmatched status from the provided local view, so we should avoid definitive claims and instead state our policy: we will consider lower-priority candidates only near the end if no higher-priority applicants materialize.

The most concrete checkpoint we can commit to is still rounds 20–25: if we reach that stage with the seat unfilled and no higher-priority applications materializing, we will reassess whether to fill the seat rather than leave it open.

You are welcome to check back then as discussed.

Given repeated rejections based on waiting for higher-priority students, round 25 is the end of their stated reassessment window, so the best move is a final clear [APPLY] emphasizing immediate acceptance and helping them avoid leaving the seat unfilled.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your continued patience and for formally applying again.

As we reach the end of our reassessment window and with no applications or concrete indications of interest from higher-priority candidates materializing, we are prepared to fill our remaining seat.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. [ACCEPT]

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_B is last on School_D’s true priority list. Our quota is 1 and remains unfilled. No higher-priority candidates (Student_D, Student_A, Student_C, Student_E) have applied or indicated interest through round 25 despite many rounds of waiting. Given the approaching end of the game (round 30) and persistent lack of higher-priority interest, the best way to secure a match (rather than risk ending unmatched) is to accept Student_B now. This still respects the constraint that Student_B is included in our priority list, and maximizes expected outcome under uncertainty.
